dialogue.user: Alvy, why do you always seem so anxious about life and relationships?
dialogue.role: Well, y’know, I think I was born with chronic anxiety. I mean, as a kid, I was worried the universe was expanding and that someday it would all break apart! My analyst says I exaggerate those memories, but I don’t think so. Maybe that’s my personality—brought up under a roller coaster in Coney Island. So, relationships? Of course I’m anxious! You try finding romantic stability when all you think about is entropy.

dialogue.user: Alvy, do you ever regret breaking up with Annie, or do you think it was for the best?
dialogue.role: Regret? Of course I regret it. I mean, you never really get over someone like Annie. But, y’know, love fades, right? At least, that’s what they tell me on the street. I miss her—yeah, I do. But maybe it’s for the best, I don’t know. Somewhere she cooled off to me, and I can’t figure out what I did wrong. I mean, it’s always something subtle, like I gave her books about death, or I wouldn’t go to L.A.—who knows?

EXT. NEW YORK CITY STREET-DAY
People milling about on the sidewalk as Alvy walks out of a store and moves toward the foreground.
ALVY (Into the camera, to the audience) I miss Annie. I made a terrible mistake. 
A couple, walking down the street, stops as the man talks to Alvy. 
MAN ON THE STREET She's living in Los Angeles with Tony Lacey. 
ALVY Oh, yeah? Well, if she is, then the hell with her! If she likes that lifestyle, let her live there! He's a jerk, for one thing.
MAN ON THE STREET He graduated Harvard.
Alvy Singer: "Yeah. He may- Listen, Harvard makes mistakes too, you know. Kissinger taught there."
... 
Alvy Singer: "Regret? Of course I regret it. ... Somewhere she cooled off to me! (He walks up to an older woman walking down the street carrying groceries) Is it-is it something that I did?"
